title: 115_hr1728
content: Boundary modification for Morley Nelson Snake River Birds of Prey National Conservation Area in Idaho. The curr_chunk provides definitions for terms related to the Morley Nelson Snake River Birds of Prey National Conservation Area, including Conservation Area, Gateway West, Map, Sage-grouse species, and Secretary. It also outlines the modification of the Conservation Area boundary. The Birds of Prey National Conservation Area boundary is modified to include 4726 acres of BLM Administered Lands and 86 acres of BOR Administered Lands, while excluding 761 acres of land along the Gateway West Transmission line. The Gateway West Transmission Line will be sited within 500 feet of the existing Summer Lake Transmission Line. The Secretary will issue a right-of-way for construction and maintenance of transmission lines on designated lands. The Gateway West Transmission Line will be constructed and maintained for transmission lines near the existing Summer Lake Transmission Line. The right-of-way issued will align with proposed routes for segments 8 and 9, with conditions for mitigation during construction in accordance with the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976. Gateway West will contribute $2,000 per acre for conservation in the Conservation Area during construction of Segment 8 and Segment 9. They will also cover costs for boundary modifications and associated expenses. The Secretary will administer lands in the Conservation Area and National Landscape Conservation System. Administrative jurisdiction over 86 acres of land is transferred from the Bureau of Reclamation to the Bureau of Land Management. A map will be available for public inspection, and a management plan amendment is required within 18 months. The Secretary will amend the management plan for the Conservation Area within 18 months to address long-term management of specified lands, including grazing and motorized access. This section allows hunting and fishing on the lands described in subsection (b)(1) subject to regulations and policies deemed necessary by the Secretary. The Cotterel Wind Power Project area on approximately 203 acres of Federal land is prohibited from being used for wind electricity production. The Bureau of Land Management Foundation is addressed in the following section. The Secretary of the Interior will establish a Bureau of Land Management Foundation as a charitable nonprofit corporation with authorities similar to the National Park Foundation. The Foundation aims to address challenges such as reclamation of legacy wells, sustainable management of wild horses, responsible development techniques, voluntary conservation activities, and identification of cultural treasures on public lands.
